question: A drain pipe can drain a tank in 12 hours, and a fill pipe can fill the same tank in 6 hours. A total of n pipes – which include a few fill pipes and the remaining drain pipes – can fill the entire tank in 2 hours. How many of the following values could 'n' take? a.24 b.16 c.33 d.13 e.9 f.8
explanation: Let number of fill pipes = x, drain pipes = n-x. Work rate: Fill pipe = 1/6 per hour, Drain pipe = -1/12 per hour. Combined rate: x/6 - (n-x)/12 = 1/2. Solving: (2x - n + x)/12 = 1/2 => (3x - n)/12 = 1/2 => 3x - n = 6 => 3x = n + 6. x must be integer ≤ n. Check which n values satisfy this.

question: Pipe A, B and C are kept open and together fill a tank in t minutes. Pipe A is kept open throughout, pipe B is kept open for the first 10 minutes and then closed. Two minutes after pipe B is closed, pipe C is opened and is kept open till the tank is full. Each pipe fills an equal share of the tank. Furthermore, it is known that if pipe A and B are kept open continuously, the tank would be filled completely in t minutes. How long will it take C alone to fill the tank?
explanation: Let work = 3 units. Each pipe does 1 unit. A works for t min, B for 10 min, C for (t-12) min. A+B fill in t min: 1/t rate. Solve equations to get C's time.

question: Pipe A fills a tank at the rate of 100lit/min, Pipe B fills at the rate of 25 lit/min, pipe C drains at the rate of 50 lit/min. The three pipes are kept open for one minute each, one after the other. If the capacity of the tank is 7000 liters, how long will it take to fill the tank if: 1.A is kept open first, followed by B and then C. 2.B first, followed by A, and then C. 3.B first, followed by C, and then A.
explanation: Calculate net filling in each 3-minute cycle for each sequence. For sequence 1: A+B+C = 100+25-50=75L in 3 min. Adjust for partial cycles.

question: 4 men and 6 women complete a task in 24 days. If the women are at least half as efficient as the men, but not more efficient than the men, what is the range of the number of days for 6 women and 2 men to complete the same task?
explanation: Let man's efficiency = m, woman's = w. Given: 4m+6w = 1/24, and 0.5m ≤ w ≤ m. Find range for 2m+6w.

question: A fill pipe can fill a tank in 20 hours, a drain pipe can drain a tank in 30 hours. If a system of n pipes (fill pipes and drain pipes put together) can fill the tank in exactly 5 hours, which of the following are possible values of n? 1.32 2.54 3.29 4.40
explanation: Let fill pipes = x, drain pipes = n-x. Rate: x/20 - (n-x)/30 = 1/5. Solve: (3x - 2n + 2x)/60 = 1/5 => (5x - 2n)/60 = 1/5 => 5x - 2n = 12 => 5x = 2n+12. x must be integer ≤ n.

question: Consider three friends A, B and C who work at differing speeds. When the slowest two work together they take n days to finish a task. When the quickest two work together they take m days to finish a task. One of them, if he worked alone would take thrice as much time as it would take when all three work together. How much time would it take if all three worked together?
explanation: Let times be a<b<c. Slowest two: b+c = n, Quickest two: a+b = m. One takes thrice combined time. Solve using work equations.

question: Pipes A, B and C can fill a tank in 30, 60 and 120 minutes respectively. Pipes B and C are kept open for 10 minutes, and then Pipe B is shut while Pipe A is opened. Pipe C is closed 10 minutes before the tank overflows. How long does it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Let total time = t minutes. Work done: B&C for 10 min, then A&C for (t-20) min, then A for last 10 min. Equation: 10(1/60+1/120) + (t-20)(1/30+1/120) + 10(1/30) = 1

question: B takes 12 more days than A to finish a task. B and A start this task and A leaves the task 12 days before the task is finished. B completes 60% of the overall task. How long would B have taken to finish the task if he had worked independently?
explanation: Let A take x days, B take x+12 days. B works full time, A works (total time - 12). B does 60% work. Set up equation and solve.

question: A and B together can finish a task in 12 days. If A worked half as efficiently as he usually does and B works thrice as efficiently as he usually does, the task gets completed in 9 days. How long would A take to finish the task if he worked independently?
explanation: Let A's time = a, B's time = b. 1/a + 1/b = 1/12. (1/2a) + (3/b) = 1/9. Solve simultaneously.

question: B takes 12 more hours than A to complete a task. If they work together, they take 16 fewer hours than B would take to complete the task. How long will it take A and B together to complete a task twice as difficult as the first one?
explanation: Let A take x hrs, B take x+12 hrs. Together: 1/x + 1/(x+12) = 1/(x+12-16) = 1/(x-4). Solve for x, then find time for double work.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank in 12 hours. When it works along with Pipe B, it can fill the tank in 8 hours. In how many hours can pipe B fill the same tank independently?
explanation: A's rate = 1/12, A+B = 1/8. B's rate = 1/8 - 1/12 = 1/24. So B takes 24 hours.

question: Number of units of a good that can be produced by a factory is directly proportional to the square of the number of workers, square root of the number of machines and to the number of hours put in. The factory produces 200 goods when 4 people work for 8 hours each with 4 machines. When 3 people work for 12 hours each with 9 machines, how many goods will be produced?
explanation: Production ∝ (workers)² × √(machines) × hours. Find constant k from first scenario, then apply to second.

question: A can complete a task in 12 days. B can complete the task in 18 days. If A and B work on this same task in alternate days starting with A, in how many days do they finish the entire task?
explanation: In 2 days: A+B = 1/12 + 1/18 = 5/36 work. In 14 days: 7 cycles = 35/36 work. Remaining 1/36 by A on 15th day: (1/36)/(1/12) = 1/3 day. Total = 14.33 days.

question: A can complete a task 4 hours lesser time than B takes to complete the same. If A and B together can complete the task in 288 minutes, how long does B alone take to complete the task?
explanation: Let B take x hours, A take x-4 hours. 1/(x-4) + 1/x = 1/(288/60) = 1/4.8. Solve quadratic equation.

question: Two pipes can fill a tank in 12 hrs and 18 hrs respectively. The pipes are opened together but due to a pipe leakage, it takes 48 minutes extra to fill the tank. If the tank is full, what time will it take to completely empty due to the leakage?
explanation: Combined fill rate = 1/12 + 1/18 = 5/36. With leakage, time = 1/(5/36 - 1/L) = 36/5 + 48/60. Solve for L.

question: A cistern of capacity 40 litres has an inlet and an outlet pipe. When both the pipes are opened at once, it takes 8 minutes to fill the cistern. However, if the outflow rate is increased 1.5 times, the cistern never gets filled. Which of the following can be the outflow rate?
explanation: Let inflow = I, outflow = O. I - O = 40/8 = 5. If 1.5O > I, then never fills. Check options.

question: A cistern of 475 litres is completely filled using pipes A and B, with Pipe A being open for 5 more hours than pipe B. If we are to interchange the operating hours of the two pipes than pipe A would have pumped half the water as much as pipe B, then find the time for which pipe B was open. Also, given that if the two pipes were open simultaneously the tank would fill in 19 hours.
explanation: Let rates: A = a, B = b. a+b = 1/19. Let B open for t hours, A for t+5. Water: a(t+5) + bt = 475. If interchanged: a(t) = 1/2 × b(t+5). Solve.

question: A mining team made a plan to mine up to 300 m in a certain number of days. After working as per plan for 5 days, they added new members to the team and hence could mine 5 m more per day. In this way, 4 days before the planned date, they had mined 295 m. How many meters of mining was initially planned for each day?
explanation: Let planned rate = r m/day, planned days = d. Total = rd = 300. Work: 5r + (d-5-4)(r+5) = 295. Solve equations.

question: Ajay and Suraj can water a garden in 45 minutes and 40 minutes respectively. They started working together but after some time Ajay left to watch a cricket match. Suraj hurriedly finished the work in next 23 minutes and joined Ajay. After how many minutes had Ajay left?
explanation: Let they worked together for t minutes. Work done: t(1/45+1/40) + 23/40 = 1. Solve for t.

question: Bibhor takes 3 hours to fetch as much water as Ahmed can fetch in 2 hours. Deepak takes 5 hours to fetch as much water as Bibhor can fetch in 4 hours. A tank takes 20 hours to fill if all work together. What time would Bibhor take to fill the tank alone?
explanation: Find efficiency ratios. Let Ahmed's rate = A. Bibhor: 3B = 2A => B = 2A/3. Deepak: 5D = 4B => D = 4B/5 = 8A/15. Together: A + 2A/3 + 8A/15 = (15A+10A+8A)/15 = 33A/15 = 11A/5. Time = 1/(11A/5) = 5/11A = 20 hrs. So A = 5/220 = 1/44. Bibhor's time = 1/B = 1/(2A/3) = 3/2A = 3/(2/44) = 66 hrs.

question: Anuj, Bibhuti and Chandu can lay 432 m of wires together in 8 days. In a day, Chandu can lay as many more meters of wire than Bibhuti as Bibhuti can lay more than Anuj. Chandu's 5 days of work is equivalent to Anuj's 7 days of work. How many meters of wire can Anuj alone lay in a day?
explanation: Let Anuj, Bibhuti, Chandu lay a, b, c m/day. Given: c - b = b - a, and 5c = 7a. Also 8(a+b+c) = 432 => a+b+c = 54. Solve equations.

question: A certain number of pages need to be typed. A, B and C are assigned to do this job. However, C leaves after 4 days when 40% of the job was complete. In this way, it takes 13 days to finish the job. Also, B can type twice as fast as A. How much would the fastest worker take to type the entire set of pages alone?
explanation: Let rates: A = x, B = 2x, C = y. Work: 4(x+2x+y) = 0.4T. Remaining: 9 days with A&B: 9(3x) = 0.6T. Solve for x,y. Fastest is B or C.

question: A, B and C are to make 100 toys. In a day, they can together make 25 toys. A starts to work alone and makes 32 toys in some days. A then leaves and B and C works to make the remaining toys. It takes 8 days overall to make the 100 toys. How many days will it take for A to make 256 toys alone?
explanation: A+B+C = 25/day. Let A work alone for d days: makes 32 toys, so A's rate = 32/d. Then B+C work for (8-d) days making 68 toys, so B+C = 68/(8-d). Also B+C = 25 - A. Solve for A's rate, then time for 256 toys.

question: Amar, Akbar and Anthony set out to complete a work. Anthony being the eldest would take 1 day less than Amar if he were to complete the work alone. All three together could complete the work in a day. However, Anthony was kidnapped by Shakal. Amar and Akbar began the work in his absence. After a day, Amar was also kidnapped. Akbar took 3 more days to finish the work. How much portion of the work Anthony could do in a day?
explanation: Let times: Amar = a, Anthony = a-1, Akbar = b. 1/a + 1/(a-1) + 1/b = 1. Work: 1 day A&Akbar + 3 days Akbar = 1. So (1/a+1/b) + 3/b = 1 => 1/a + 4/b = 1. Solve equations.

question: It's year 2025 and iphone16 has just been launched. Apple has claimed that it is the best iphone they have created so far. It's 4 charging inlets have completely revolutionized the mobile market. If only top and bottom inlets are used, it takes 20 mins to fully charge. If the right, left and bottom inlet are used, it takes 15 mins to fully charge. If top, left and right inlets are used, it takes 12 mins to charge. What is the fastest possible time in which the iphone16 can be fully charged?
explanation: Let rates: Top=T, Bottom=B, Left=L, Right=R. Equations: T+B=1/20, R+L+B=1/15, T+L+R=1/12. Add first and third: 2T+B+L+R=1/20+1/12=2/15. Subtract second: 2T=2/15-1/15=1/15 => T=1/30. Similarly find others. All four together rate = T+B+L+R.

question: Rahul, Rakshita and Gurmeet, working together, would have taken more than 7 days to finish a job. On the other hand, Rahul and Gurmeet, working together would have taken less than 15 days to finish the job. However, they all worked together for 6 days, followed by Rakshita, who worked alone for 3 more days to finish the job. If Rakshita had worked alone on the job then the number of days she would have taken to finish the job, cannot be
explanation: Let times: Rl, Rk, Gm. Given: 1/Rl+1/Rk+1/Gm < 1/7, 1/Rl+1/Gm > 1/15. Work: 6(1/Rl+1/Rk+1/Gm) + 3/Rk = 1. Find range for Rk.

question: Gautam and Suhani, working together, can finish a job in 20 days. If Gautam does only 60% of his usual work on a day, Suhani must do 150% of her usual work on that day to exactly make up for it. Then, the number of days required by the faster worker to complete the job working alone is
explanation: Let G's rate = g, S's rate = s. g+s=1/20. Also 0.6g + 1.5s = g+s => 0.4g = 0.5s => g/s=5/4. Faster is G. Solve for g.

question: Pipes A and C are fill pipes while Pipe B is a drain pipe of a tank. Pipe B empties the full tank in one hour less than the time taken by Pipe A to fill the empty tank. When pipes A, B and C are turned on together, the empty tank is filled in two hours. If pipes B and C are turned on together when the tank is empty and Pipe B is turned off after one hour, then Pipe C takes another one hour and 15 minutes to fill the remaining tank. If Pipe A can fill the empty tank in less than five hours, then the time taken, in minutes, by Pipe C to fill the empty tank is
explanation: Let A's time = a hrs, B's time = a-1 hrs, C's time = c hrs. Equations: 1/a - 1/(a-1) + 1/c = 1/2. Also: 1(1/c - 1/(a-1)) + 1.25/c = 1. Solve with a<5.

question: The amount of job that Amal, Sunil and Kamal can individually do in a day, are in harmonic progression. Kamal takes twice as much time as Amal to do the same amount of job. If Amal and Sunil work for 4 days and 9 days, respectively, Kamal needs to work for 16 days to finish the remaining job. Then the number of days Sunil will take to finish the job working alone, is
explanation: Rates in HP => 1/A, 1/S, 1/K in AP. Also K=2A. Work: 4/A + 9/S + 16/K = 1. Use relationships to solve for S.

question: Bob can finish a job in 40 days, if he works alone. Alex is twice as fast as Bob and thrice as fast as Cole in the same job. Suppose Alex and Bob work together on the first day, Bob and Cole work together on the second day, Cole and Alex work together on the third day, and then, they continue the work by repeating this three-day roster, with Alex and Bob working together on the fourth day, and so on. Then, the total number of days Alex would have worked when the job gets finished, is
explanation: Rates: Bob=1/40, Alex=1/20, Cole=1/60. Work in 3-day cycle: Day1: 1/20+1/40=3/40, Day2: 1/40+1/60=1/24, Day3: 1/60+1/20=1/15. Total per cycle = 3/40+1/24+1/15 = 9/120+5/120+8/120=22/120=11/60. Find complete cycles and remaining work.

question: A group of N people worked on a project. They finished 35% of the project by working 7 hours a day for 10 days. Thereafter, 10 people left the group and the remaining people finished the rest of the project in 14 days by working 10 hours a day. Then the value of N is
explanation: Work = N × 7 × 10 = 70N man-hours for 35%. Remaining 65% done by (N-10) × 10 × 14 = 140(N-10) man-hours. So 70N/35 = 140(N-10)/65. Solve for N.

question: Working alone, the times taken by Anu, Tanu and Manu to complete any job are in the ratio 5:8:10. They accept a job which they can finish in 4 days if they all work together for 8 hours per day. However, Anu and Tanu work together for the first 6 days, working 6 hours 40 minutes per day. Then, the number of hours that Manu will take to complete the remaining job working alone is

Anil can paint a house in 60 days while Bimal can paint it in 84 days. Anil starts painting and after 10 days, Bimal and Charu join him. Together, they complete the painting in 14 more days. If they are paid a total of ₹ 21000 for the job, then the share of Charu, in INR, proportionate to the work done by him, is

Anil alone can do a job in 20 days while Sunil alone can do it in 40 days. Anil starts the job, and after 3 days, Sunil joins him. Again, after a few more days, Bimal joins them and they together finish the job. If Bimal has done 10% of the job, then in how many days was the job done?
explanation: Let total work=1. Bimal does 0.1. Anil & Sunil do 0.9. Let Anil work x days, Sunil (x-3) days. x/20 + (x-3)/40 = 0.9. Solve for x.

question: At their usual efficiency levels, A and B together finish a task in 12 days. If A had worked half as efficiently as she usually does, and B had worked thrice as efficiently as he usually does, the task would have been completed in 9 days. How many days would A take to finish the task if she works alone at her usual efficiency?
explanation: Let A's time=a, B's time=b. 1/a+1/b=1/12. 1/2a+3/b=1/9. Solve simultaneously.

question: Three men and eight machines can finish a job in half the time taken by three machines and eight men to finish the same job. If two machines can finish the job in 13 days, then how many men can finish the job in 13 days?
explanation: Let man's rate=m, machine's rate=k. Given: 3m+8k = 2(8m+3k) => 3m+8k=16m+6k => 2k=13m => k=6.5m. Also 2k=1/13 => k=1/26, m=1/169. Men needed for 13 days: n×1/169×13=1 => n=13.

question: A tank is emptied everyday at a fixed time point. Immediately thereafter, either pump A or pump B or both start working until the tank is full. On Monday, A alone completed filling the tank at 8 pm. On Tuesday, B alone completed filling the tank at 6 pm. On Wednesday, A alone worked till 5 pm, and then B worked alone from 5 pm to 7 pm, to fill the tank. At what time was the tank filled on Thursday if both pumps were used simultaneously all along?
explanation: Let filling start time = T, capacity=C. A's rate=a, B's rate=b. Monday: A works from T to 8pm, so a(20-T)=C. Tuesday: B works from T to 6pm, so b(18-T)=C. Wednesday: A from T to 5pm + B from 5pm to 7pm: a(17-T)+2b=C. Solve for T,a,b. Thursday both: time t from T: (a+b)t=C.

question: Ramesh and Ganesh can together complete a work in 16 days. After seven days of working together, Ramesh got sick and his efficiency fell by 30%. As a result, they completed the work in 17 days instead of 16 days. If Ganesh had worked alone after Ramesh got sick, in how many days would he have completed the remaining work?
explanation: Let R's rate=r, G's rate=g. r+g=1/16. Work: 7/16 + 10(0.7r+g)=1. Solve for g. Remaining after 7 days=9/16. G's time=(9/16)/g.

question: A water tank has inlets of two types A and B. All inlets of type A when open, bring in water at the same rate. All inlets of type B, when open, bring in water at the same rate. The empty tank is completely filled in 30 minutes if 10 inlets of type A and 45 inlets of type B are open, and in 1 hour if 8 inlets of type A and 18 inlets of type B are open. In how many minutes will the empty tank get completely filled if 7 inlets of type A and 27 inlets of type B are open?
explanation: Let rate of A=a, B=b. Capacity C. 30(10a+45b)=C, 60(8a+18b)=C. Solve for a,b in terms of C. Then find time for 7a+27b.

question: When they work alone, B needs 25% more time to finish a job than A does. They two finish the job in 13 days in the following manner: A works alone till half the job is done, then A and B work together for four days, and finally B works alone to complete the remaining 5% of the job. In how many days can B alone finish the entire job?
explanation: Let A's time=a, B's time=1.25a. Work: A alone till 50%, then A+B 4 days, then B alone 5%. Equation: 0.5/(1/a) + 4(1/a+1/1.25a) + 0.05/(1/1.25a)=13. Solve for a, then B's time.

question: Humans and robots can both perform a job but at different efficiencies. Fifteen humans and five robots working together take thirty days to finish the job, whereas five humans and fifteen robots working together take sixty days to finish it. How many days will fifteen humans working together (without any robot) take to finish it?
explanation: Let human rate=h, robot rate=r. 30(15h+5r)=1, 60(5h+15r)=1. Solve for h,r. Then time for 15h=1/(15h).

question: A tank is fitted with pipes, some filling it and the rest draining it. All filling pipes fill at the same rate, and all draining pipes drain at the same rate. The empty tank gets completely filled in 6 hours when 6 filling and 5 draining pipes are on, but this time becomes 60 hours when 5 filling and 6 draining pipes are on. In how many hours will the empty tank get completely filled when one draining and two filling pipes are on?
explanation: Let fill rate=f, drain rate=d. 6(6f-5d)=1, 60(5f-6d)=1. Solve for f,d. Then time for 2f-1d=1/(2f-d).

question: A tank has an inlet pipe and an outlet pipe. If the outlet pipe is closed then the inlet pipe fills the empty tank in 8 hours. If the outlet pipe is open then the inlet pipe fills the empty tank in 10 hours. If only the outlet pipe is open then in how many hours the full tank becomes half-full?
explanation: Inlet rate=1/8. With outlet, net rate=1/10. So outlet rate=1/8-1/10=1/40. Time to empty half=0.5/(1/40)=20 hours.

question: Amal can complete a job in 10 days and Bimal can complete it in 8 days. Amal, Bimal and Kamal together complete the job in 4 days and are paid a total amount of Rs 1000 as remuneration. If this amount is shared by them in proportion to their work, then Kamal's share, in rupees, is

A person can complete a job in 120 days. He works alone on Day 1. On Day 2, he is joined by another person who also can complete the job in exactly 120 days. On Day 3, they are joined by another person of equal efficiency. Like this, everyday a new person with the same efficiency joins the work. How many days are required to complete the job?
explanation: Work on day n = n/120. Cumulative work after d days = Σn/120 from n=1 to d = d(d+1)/240 = 1. Solve d(d+1)=240 => d=15.

question: Two pipes P and Q can fill a tank in 20hrs and 25hrs respectively while a third pipe R can empty the tank in 30hrs. If all the pipes are opened together for 10hrs and then pipe R is closed then in what time the tank can be filled.

Work done by P in one day is double the work done by Q in one day and work done by Q in one day is thrice the work done by R in one day. If P, Q and R together can complete the work in 30 days then in how many days P alone can do the work?
explanation: Let R's work/day=r, then Q=3r, P=6r. Together=10r=1/30 => r=1/300. P's time=1/(6/300)=300/6=50 days.

question: In a factory there are three types of machines b1, b2, and b3 which produces 20%, 15%, and 32% of the total products respectively. Further, machines b1, b2, and b3 which produces 3%, 7%, and 2% defective products respectively. Find the percentage of non-defective products?
explanation: Non-defective = 0.20×0.97 + 0.15×0.93 + 0.32×0.98 + (1-0.20-0.15-0.32)=0.194+0.1395+0.3136+0.33=0.9771 ≈ 97.71% but options are 0.46,0.3,0.53,0.64. Wait, maybe remaining 33% from other machines with 100% non-defective? Then 0.194+0.1395+0.3136+0.33=0.9771. But options are less than 1. Perhaps they mean defective percentage? 1-0.9771=0.0229. Not matching. There might be error in question or options.

question: Imagine that there are four hundred and fifty nine managers in a hotel. If the number of managers is enlarged by 36, the expenses of the food increased by Rs. eighty one per day while the average spending per head decreased by one. Find the original spending of the hotel on food?
explanation: Let original avg=x. Original total=459x. New: 495 managers, avg=x-1, total=495(x-1). Given: 495(x-1)-459x=81. Solve: 495x-495-459x=81 => 36x=576 => x=16. Original spending=459×16=7344.

question: Three workers working together need 1 hour to construct a wall. The first worker, working alone, can construct the wall twice as fast at the third worker, and can complete the task an hour sooner than the second worker. Then, the average time in hours taken by the three workers, when working alone, to construct the wall is
explanation: Let times: A=a, B=b, C=c. Given: 1/a+1/b+1/c=1, a=c/2, b=a+1=c/2+1. Substitute and solve quadratic for c. Then average=(a+b+c)/3.

question: A cistern has two taps attached to it. Tap B can empty the cistern in 45 minutes. But Tap A can fill the cistern in just 30 minutes. Rohit started both taps unknowingly but realized his mistake after 30 minutes. He immediately closed Tap B. Now after this, in how much time will the cistern be filled?
explanation: Net rate when both open = 1/30 - 1/45 = 1/90 (filling). In 30 minutes, filled = 30/90 = 1/3. Remaining = 2/3. After closing B, only A works at rate 1/30. Time = (2/3)/(1/30) = 20 minutes.

question: Pipe R can empty a full tank in 30 hours. But two pipes P and Q can fill a tank in 15 hours and 10 hours respectively. Ram unknowingly opened all three taps. After 2 hours Shyam realized it and closed Pipe R. Due to this mistake how much time more would it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Net rate first 2 hours = 1/15 + 1/10 - 1/30 = 2/30 + 3/30 - 1/30 = 4/30 = 2/15. Work done = 4/15. Remaining = 11/15. Rate after closing R = 1/15 + 1/10 = 1/6. Time = (11/15)/(1/6) = 66/15 = 4.4 hours = 4 hours 24 minutes. Extra time = 4h24m - normal time. Normal time = 1/(1/6)=6 hours. So extra = 4h24m - 6h? Wait, need to find additional time due to mistake.

question: A cistern is filled by Pipe A and Pipe B together in 2.4 hours. Pipe A alone can fill the cistern at the rate of 100 litres per hour. Pipe B alone can fill the cistern in 4 hours. What is the capacity of the cistern?
explanation: A's rate = 100 L/hr, time = C/100 hours. B's time = 4 hours, rate = C/4. Together: 100 + C/4 = C/2.4. Solve: 100 + C/4 = 5C/12 => Multiply 12: 1200 + 3C = 5C => 2C=1200 => C=600 litres.

question: There is a leak at the bottom of a cistern. Due to this it takes 8 hours to fill the cistern. Had there not been a leak, it would take one hour less to fill the cistern. How much time does it take for the leak to completely empty the cistern?
explanation: Let fill rate = F, leak rate = L. With leak: 1/(F-L) = 8 => F-L = 1/8. Without leak: 1/F = 7 => F = 1/7. So L = F - 1/8 = 1/7 - 1/8 = 1/56. Time to empty = 1/L = 56 hours.

question: Tap P alone fills a cistern in 2 hours; while tap Q alone fills the same cistern in 3 hours. A new tap R is attached to the bottom of the cistern which can empty the completely filled cistern in 6 hours. Sunny started all three taps together at 9am. When will the tank be full?
explanation: Net rate = 1/2 + 1/3 - 1/6 = 3/6 + 2/6 - 1/6 = 4/6 = 2/3 per hour. Time = 1/(2/3) = 1.5 hours. From 9am, tank full at 10:30am.

question: A cistern can be filled in 6 hours by taps P and Q. If tap R also joins them, then cistern is filled in 5 hours. Tap P can fill the cistern at twice the rate of tap Q. In what time tap Q and R fill the cistern?
A cistern is normally filled with water in 10 hours but takes 5 hours longer to fill because of a leak in its bottom. If the cistern is full, the leak will empty the cistern in
explanation: Normal fill rate=1/10. With leak: time=15 hours, rate=1/15. Leak rate=1/10-1/15=1/30. Time to empty=1/(1/30)=30 hours.

question: A tank has three taps P, Q and R. Taps P and Q can fill the tank in 1.5 and 2 hours, respectively. Tap R can empty the completely filled tank in just half hour. Tap P is opened at 8 am, tap Q is opened at 9am and tap R is opened at 10 am. At what exact time will the tank be empty?
explanation: Rates: P=2/3 per hr, Q=1/2 per hr, R=2 per hr (empty). Work: 8-9: P fills 2/3. 9-10: P+Q fill 2/3+1/2=7/6. Total at 10am=2/3+7/6=11/6. After 10am, net rate=P+Q-R=2/3+1/2-2=4/6+3/6-12/6=-5/6. Time to empty= (11/6)/(5/6)=2.2 hours=2h12m. From 10am => 12:12pm.

question: A pipe can fill a tank in 6 hours. Another pipe can empty the tank in 12 hours. If both pipes are opened simultaneously, the part of tank filled by both pipes in 1 hour is?
explanation: Net rate=1/6-1/12=1/12. So 1/12th part in 1 hour.

question: A tap having diameter 'd' can empty a tank in 84 min. How long another tap having diameter '2d' take to empty the same tank?
explanation: Flow rate ∝ area ∝ d². New tap diameter 2d, area 4 times, so rate 4 times. Time = 84/4 = 21 minutes.

question: Pipe A can fill a tank 5 times faster than Pipe B and takes 32 minutes less than Pipe B to fill the tank. If both the pipes are opened together, then in how much time the tank would be full?
explanation: Let B's time=t, A's time=t/5. Given: t - t/5 = 32 => 4t/5=32 => t=40 minutes. So A=8 min, B=40 min. Together rate=1/8+1/40=6/40=3/20. Time=20/3 minutes.

question: Two pipes M and N can fill a tank in 22.5 and 15 minutes, respectively. If both the pipes are opened simultaneously, after how much time should N be closed so that the tank is full in 18 minutes?
explanation: Let N work for t minutes. Work: M works 18 min, N works t min. 18/22.5 + t/15 = 1 => 0.8 + t/15 = 1 => t/15=0.2 => t=3 minutes.

question: Two pipes M and N are opened together to fill a tank. Both the pipes fill the tank in time X minutes. When M alone is filling the tank, it takes 9 minutes more time than X to fill the tank. In a similar manner N takes 16 minutes more time than X to fill the tank. What is the value of X?

Pipe P can fill a tank in 38 hours. Pipe Q alone can fill it in 19 hours. Pipe R can empty the full tank in 133 hours. If all the pipes are opened together, how much time will be needed to make the tank full?

Two pipes M and N can fill a pool in 40 minutes and 60 minutes, respectively. The entire pool can completely be emptied by another pipe P in 30 minutes. M, N and P are opened alternatively and each is kept open for just 1 minute. In how much time will the pool be filled?
explanation: In 3-minute cycle: M=1/40, N=1/60, P=-1/30. Net=1/40+1/60-1/30=3/120+2/120-4/120=1/120. So 120 cycles=360 minutes for 1 pool, but last cycle won't need full negative. Calculate exactly.

question: A tap can fill a tub in 24 hours. Due to a leak at the bottom of the tub, the tap fills the tub in 36 hours. If the tub is full, how much time will the leak take to empty it?
explanation: Fill rate=1/24. With leak=1/36. Leak rate=1/24-1/36=1/72. Time to empty=72 hours.

question: 3 pipes have diameters 2 cms, 3 cms and 4 cms. The ratio of water flowing through them is equal to the ratio of the square of their diameters. The biggest pipe when open alone, can fill the entire pool in just 126 minutes. When all the pipes are opened together, the pool would be filled in how much time?
Two pipes M and N can fill a tank in 22 hours and 33 hours respectively. In how much time will the tank be full, if both the pipes are opened simultaneously?
explanation: Together rate=1/22+1/33=3/66+2/66=5/66. Time=66/5=13.2 hours=13 hours 12 minutes=13(1/5) hours.

question: A water tank has two pipes to fill water in it. One of the pipes fills water at the rate of 100 litres per hour. The tank is filled by the other pipe in 6 hours and by both pipes together in 4.2 hours. What is the capacity of the tank in litres?
explanation: Let capacity=C. Second pipe rate=C/6. Both: 100 + C/6 = C/4.2. Solve: 100 + C/6 = 10C/42 = 5C/21. Multiply 42: 4200 + 7C = 10C => 3C=4200 => C=1400 litres.

question: Pipe P can fill a tank in 4 hours, pipe Q in 8 hours and pipe R in 24 hours. If all the pipes are open, in how many hours will the tank be filled?
Two pipes P and Q can fill a tank in 10 hours and 14 hours respectively. If both pipes are opened simultaneously, how much time will be taken to fill the tank?
explanation: Together rate=1/10+1/14=7/70+5/70=12/70=6/35. Time=35/6=5.833 hours=5 hours 50 minutes ≈ 5 hours 49 min.

question: A inlet pipe can fill a tank in 12 hours and an outlet pipe can empty the tank in 16 hours. If both the pipes are opened simultaneously, find the time taken to fill the tank.
If pipe A can fill the tank in 45 minutes and pipe B in 30 minutes, find the time to fill the tank if both the pipes are opened together.
If a pipe can fill a tank in 6 hours, find the part of tank it fills in one hour.
explanation: In 1 hour, fills 1/6 of tank.

question: A leak at the bottom of the tank can empty the tank in 5 hours, while an inlet pipe can fill the same tank at the rate of 6 litres per minute. When the tank is full, the inlet is opened and the tank gets empty in 8 hours due to the leakage. Find the capacity of the tank.
explanation: Let capacity=C litres. Leak rate=C/5 litres per hour. Inlet rate=6×60=360 litres per hour. When both open, net rate=360 - C/5. Time to empty=C/(C/5 - 360)=8 hours. So C=8(C/5-360) => C=8C/5-2880 => 3C/5=2880 => C=4800 litres.

question: Pipes A and B fill a tank in 5 and 6 hours respectively. Pipe C empties the tank in 12 hours, if you open all the three pipes together this tank will be filled in?
Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 12 and 24 minutes respectively. If both the pipes are used together, how long will it take to fill the tank?
explanation: Together rate=1/12+1/24=2/24+1/24=3/24=1/8. Time=8 minutes.

question: Two pipes A and B can fill a cistern in 37.5 minutes and 45 minutes respectively. This cistern will be filled in half an hour if both the pipes are opened together initially and pipe B is then turned off after X minutes. What is X?
explanation: Let B work for X minutes. Work: A works 30 min, B works X min. 30/37.5 + X/45 = 1 => 0.8 + X/45 = 1 => X/45=0.2 => X=9 minutes.

question: Two pipes A and B can fill a tank in 24 minutes and 32 minutes respectively. If both the pipes are opened simultaneously, after how much time should B be closed so that the tank is full in 18 minutes?
explanation: Let B work for t minutes. Work: A works 18 min, B works t min. 18/24 + t/32 = 1 => 0.75 + t/32 = 1 => t/32=0.25 => t=8 minutes.

question: A pipe is 30 m long and is 45% longer than another pipe. Find the length of the other pipe.
explanation: Let other pipe length=L. 30 = L + 0.45L = 1.45L. So L=30/1.45=20.689≈20.68m.

question: A,B and c together earn Rs. 300 a day, while A and C together earn Rs.188 and B and C together earn Rs. 152 a day. What is the daily earning of C?
explanation: A+B+C=300, A+C=188, B+C=152. Subtract second from first: B=112. Subtract third from first: A=148. Then C=300-112-148=40.

question: A and B together can do a piece of work In 6 days and A alone can do It in 9 days,. In how days B alone do it?
explanation: A+B=1/6, A=1/9. B=1/6-1/9=1/18. So B takes 18 days alone.

question: A alone can finish a job in 12 days and B alone can do It In 20 days. If they work together and finish it, then the share of A In total wages of Rs100 is
explanation: Work ratio = efficiency ratio = 1/12 : 1/20 = 5:3. A's share = 5/8 × 100 = Rs.62.50

question: Two pipes, P and Q can fill a cistern in 12 and 15 minutes respectively. Both are opened together, but at the end of 3 minutes the first Is turned off. How much longer will the cistern take to fill completely?
A certain number of men can do a work in 60 days. If there were 8 more men, it could be finished in 10 days less. How many men are there?
explanation: Let men=m. Work = 60m. Also work = (m+8)×50. So 60m=50m+400 => 10m=400 => m=40.

question: Two men undertake to do a piece of work for Rs.200. One alone could do it in 6 days, the other In 8 days. With the assistance of a boy they finish it in 3 days. What Is the share of the boy?

A contract Is to be completed In 56 days and 104 men were set to work, each working 8 hours a day. After 30 days, 2/5 of the work Is finished. How many additional men may be employed so that work may be completed on time?
explanation: Work done=104×30×8=24960 man-hours for 2/5 work. Total work=62400 man-hours. Remaining work=3/5=37440 man-hours. Remaining days=26, hours/day=8. Men needed=37440/(26×8)=180. Additional=180-104=76 men.

question: Two coal loading machines each working 12 hours per day for 8 days handles 9 tons of coal with an efficiency of 90%. While 3 other coal loading machines at an efficiency of 80% set to handle 12 tons of coal In 6 days. Find how many hours per day each should work?
explanation: First case: 2×12×8×0.9=172.8 machine-hours for 9 tons. Rate=9/172.8=5/96 tons per machine-hour. Second case: 3 machines, 6 days, h hours/day, efficiency 80%. Work=3×6×h×0.8×(5/96)=12. Solve: 14.4h/96×5=12 => 72h/96=12 => h=16 hours.

question: If the cost of printing a book of 320 leaves with 21 lines On each page and on an average 11 words in each line is Rs.19, then find the cost of printing a book with 297 leaves,28 lines on each page and 10 words In each line.
explanation: Cost ∝ leaves × lines × words. First book: 320×21×11=73920 units. Second: 297×28×10=83160 units. Cost=19×83160/73920=19×1.125=21.375=Rs.21 3/8? Wait calculation: 83160/73920=1.125 exactly. 19×1.125=21.375=21 3/8. But option B is 20 3/8. Let me recalc: 297×28×10=83160, 320×21×11=73920. Ratio=83160/73920=1.125. 19×1.125=21.375. But options: A=22.375, B=20.375, C=21.375, D=21.75. So correct is C? But answer marked B? There's discrepancy.

question: A can do a job in 10 days. B can do in 12 days and C can do in 15 days. All begin together but A leaves the work after 2 days and B leaves 3 days before the work is finished. How long did the work last?
explanation: Let total time=t days. A works 2 days, B works (t-3) days, C works t days. Work: 2/10 + (t-3)/12 + t/15 = 1. Solve: 0.2 + (t-3)/12 + t/15 = 1 => Multiply 60: 12 + 5(t-3) + 4t = 60 => 12+5t-15+4t=60 => 9t=63 => t=7 days.

question: Three labourers started working together to complete a task in certain number of days. But in the course of work, they remained absent for few days due to some unavoidable circumstances and therefore the work was completed 3 days late. If the first and second labourers remained absent for 2 and 4 days more than the third labourer remained, then the third labourer remained absent for
explanation: Let planned days=d, actual=d+3. Let third absent=a days, first absent=a+2, second absent=a+4. Each has same efficiency. Total mandays planned=3d. Actual mandays=3(d+3)-(3a+6)=3d+9-3a-6=3d+3-3a. Since work same: 3d=3d+3-3a => 3a=3 => a=1 day.

question: Three labourers started working together to complete a task in certain number of days. But in the course of work, they remained absent for few days due to some unavoidable circumstances and therefore the work was completed 3 days late. If the first and second labourers got Rs 10 and Rs 20 less than the third labourer got, then the extra money the third labourer earned is
explanation: Wage per day same. Let third worked x days more than first, and y days more than second. First got 10 less, second 20 less than third. So third worked 1 day more than first, 2 days more than second. Extra money=wage for extra days.

question: Three labourers started working together to complete a task in certain number of days. But in the course of work, they remained absent for few days due to some unavoidable circumstances and therefore the work was completed 3 days late. If the first and second labourers got Rs 80 and Rs 100 less than the third labourer got, then the wage per day per labourer is
explanation: First got 80 less, second 100 less than third. So third worked 8 days more than first, 10 days more than second? But they started together and finished together. This seems inconsistent.

question: Three labourers started working together to complete a task in certain number of days. But in the course of work, they remained absent for few days due to some unavoidable circumstances and therefore the work was completed 3 days late. If the first and second labourers got Rs 15 and Rs 30 less than the third labourer got, then the third labourer remained absent for
explanation: Wage difference indicates days difference. First got 15 less, second 30 less than third. So third worked 1.5 days more than first? Not integer. Problematic question.

question: Ram is twice as efficient as Sunita and can finish a piece of work in 25 days less than Sunita. Sunita can finish this work in how many days?
explanation: Let Sunita's time=t, Ram's time=t-25. Ram is twice efficient, so t=2(t-25) => t=2t-50 => t=50 days.

question: A can do a piece of work in 16 days, and B can do the same work in 12 days. With the help of C, they finished the work in 6 days. C can do the work in how many days, working alone?
Chetan is thrice as efficient as Mamta and together they can finish a piece of work in 60 days. Mamta will take how many days to finish this work alone?
explanation: Let Mamta's rate=m, Chetan's rate=3m. Together=4m=1/60 => m=1/240. Mamta takes 240 days.

question: Mr. Ram has a sum of money, which is sufficient to pay Usha's wages for 30 days and Manika's wages for 60 days. If he employs them together, the money is sufficient to pay their wages for how many days?
explanation: Let total money=M. Usha's daily wage=M/30, Manika's=M/60. Together daily=M/30+M/60=M/20. Days=M/(M/20)=20 days.

question: X can do a piece of work in 20 days. He worked at it for 5 days and then Y finished it in 15 days. In how many days can X and Y together finish the work?
explanation: X's 5 days work=5/20=1/4. Remaining=3/4 done by Y in 15 days, so Y's rate=(3/4)/15=1/20. Together rate=1/20+1/20=1/10. Time=10 days.

question: X can do a piece of work in 30 days. Y can do it in 20 days, and Z can do it in 24 days. In how many days will they all do it together?
M and N can do a piece of work in 8 days and O can do it in 24 days. In how many days will M, N, and O do it together?
One man can paint a house in '10' days and another man can do it in 15 days. If they work together, they can do it in 'd' days, then the value of 'd' is
A can do a piece of work in 9 days and B in 18 days. They begin together, but A goes away three days before the work is finished. The work lasts for
explanation: Let total time=t days. A works (t-3) days, B works t days. (t-3)/9 + t/18 = 1. Multiply 18: 2(t-3)+t=18 => 2t-6+t=18 => 3t=24 => t=8 days.

question: It takes 'h' hours to mow a lawn. In one hour what part of the lawn is mowed?
explanation: In 1 hour, mows 1/h part of lawn.

question: In the beginning, Ram works at a rate such that he can finish a piece of work in 24 hrs, but he only works at this rate for 16 hrs. After that, he works at a rate such that he can do the whole work in 18 hrs. If Ram is to finish this work at a stretch, how many hours will he take to finish this work?
explanation: First 16 hours: work=16/24=2/3. Remaining=1/3. Second rate=1/18 per hour. Time for remaining=(1/3)/(1/18)=6 hours. Total=16+6=22 hours.

question: A can do a piece of work in 10 days, and B can do the same work in 20 days. With the help of C, they finished the work in 4 days. C can do the work in how many days, working alone?
A can do a piece of work in 12 days. B can do this work in 16 days. A started the work alone. After how many days should B join him, so that the work is finished in 9 days?
explanation: Let A work alone for d days, then both for (9-d) days. d/12 + (9-d)(1/12+1/16)=1 => d/12 + (9-d)(7/48)=1. Multiply 48: 4d + 7(9-d)=48 => 4d+63-7d=48 => -3d=-15 => d=5 days.

question: A and B can do a piece of work in 4 days, while C and D can do the same work in 12 days. In how many days will A, B, C and D do it together?
A and B can do a piece of work in 40 days, B and C can do it in 120 days. If B alone can do it in 180 days, in how many days will A and C do it together?
A, B, C, and D can do a piece of work in 20 days. If A and B can do it together in 50 days, and C alone in 60 days, find the time in which D alone can do it.
A, B, and C can do a piece of work in 8 days. B and C together do it in 24 days. B alone can do it in 40 days. In what time will it be done by C working alone?
A and B undertake to do a piece of work for Rs. 450. A can do it in 20 days and B can do it in 40 days. With the help of C, they finish it in 8 days. How much should C be paid for his contribution?

Daku and Tamatar can do a piece of work in 70 and 60 days respectively. They began the work together, but Daku leaves after some days and Tamatar finished the remaining work in 47 days. After how many days did Daku leave?

Ajay and Vijay undertake to do a piece of work for Rs. 480. Ajay alone can do it in 75 days while Vijay alone can do it in 40 days. With the help of Pradeep, they finish the work in 25 days. How much should Pradeep get for his work?

Mahesh asked 32 men to build his house in 20 days. 80% of the work got completed in just 12 days. So Mahesh removed some workers. Now how many persons does he need to complete the remaining work in decided time?
explanation: Work=32×20=640 man-days. 80% work=512 man-days done in 12 days by 32 men=384 man-days. So 512-384=128 man-days extra? Wait, 80% in 12 days by 32 men=384 man-days, but should be 512, so ahead. Remaining 20% work=128 man-days in 8 days. Men needed=128/8=16 men. But he had 32, so removed 16. Question asks how many needed? 16. But option A is 12. Let's recalc: Total work=32×20=640. 80% work=512. In 12 days, 32 men do 384. So work done=384, but should be 512? This doesn't match. Probably means: 80% work completed in 12 days (ahead of schedule). So work done=512 worth in 12 days. Rate=512/12 per day with 32 men. So per man rate=512/(12×32)=4/3 per day. Remaining work=20% of 640=128. Remaining days=8. Men needed=128/(8×4/3)=128×3/32=12 men.

question: A takes twice as much time as B or thrice as much time as C to finish a piece of work; working together they can finish the work in 2 days. B can do the work alone in
A can do 1/4th part of work in 10 days and B can do 40% work in 40 days and C can do 1/3rd of the work in 13 days. Who will complete the work first?
explanation: A: 1/4 in 10 days => full in 40 days. B: 40% in 40 days => full in 100 days. C: 1/3 in 13 days => full in 39 days. Fastest is C (39 days).

question: A and B can finish a piece of work in 30 days, B and C can finish it in 15 days, C and A in 10 days. Time taken by them together to do this work is?
P and Q can do a work in 12 days. Q and R can do the same work in 16 days, and R and P can do it in 24 days. Find the time in which P, Q and R can finish the work together.
If 3 men can do a work in 2 days and 4 boys can do the same work in 6 days, then in how many days will the same work be completed by 8 men and 8 boys?
explanation: Man's rate: 3 men in 2 days => 1 man=1/6 per day. Boy's rate: 4 boys in 6 days => 1 boy=1/24 per day. 8 men+8 boys=8/6+8/24=4/3+1/3=5/3 per day. Time=1/(5/3)=3/5 days.
